Mar 22

5 years to perfect the “To Do List”. And now it’s yours for FREE… instantly.

As a trained co-active life coach I have been obsessed with #productivity and “to do” lists. I have had monthly to do lists. Then weekly. Then daily…. With these lists… done in a certain way, I have become more successful than I ever imagined work wise.

So in the spirit of giving — after my birthday week — I am giving my how to create these power lists — to you — for FREE.

Do You Even List?

The scientific proof behind to do lists is already vast and well documented so if you don’t make to do lists already — you should do. But there is a certain way you can make them. It took me five years to create a really bullet proof methodology for the perfect to do list.

Here it is…Steal it from me. Actually, I am giving it you so… It’s a bit long, but heck, so is five years, so…

The perfect to do list.

Many people simply make a list. That’s great. But for extra motivation — add in some more detail. So you have your normal to do list. Like this.

And to this I would add.

How long you think each task will take you. So you don’t put too much into one day.

And… Then when you are going to do it. I like to plan ahead — a month ahead if possible from day to day. Two weeks if things are continually in flux and changing. As you need to be as specific as possible — so it’s on Monday 13th Jan — then the action.

I then found it useful to then add WHY you are doing it — what’s the reason behind it — what’s your end goal.

So it looks like this…

A bit more advanced…

Urgent / Important

And then for extra efficiency and productivity — you could think each item on the list.

What’s important and what’s urgent?

This what Stephen Covey says you should do — so hat tip to him for this. So you can make one column for “important” and one for “urgent” and mark each action out of ten. Then you can add the numbers together and divide by two.

Giving YOU an average score out of ten.

I personally then take out anything that is less than a 6. This is so I only concentrate on doing things that are worth doing. My list then looks like this….

To this I later added — a time factor to it. Not how long it would take but whether this helps achieve a short term, mid term or long term goal.

Why? Separate your time thinking like this?

This meant that if one month I was simply fighting fires i.e. only short term moments or only making money. Then I had to look into doing more long term stuff like personal brand building and blogging.

Normally I go for a traditional 60 / 30 / 10 split which I use in marketing all the time. Hat tip to Jeremy Waite.

And as often have multiple clients or multiple hats on. Which I am sure we all do. I added different codes for different clients or areas that were important in my life.

So Great Marketing Works actions (GMW), actions for my clients like UTC Media City (UTC), or personal actions and family life. Which looks like this:

Why?

The reason I do this is so you can see at the end of the month where you have put your attention and energy. Remember the wisdom of Deepak Chopra here as:

“Attention energizes and intention transforms. What we place our attention on expands in our lives.”

You can then look at what you have been up to and see who it’s been for. So you might have a column for work, for friends and family and one for your hobby. For myself, in January it was for my startup project FFFlip and my marketing training agency work with Great Marketing Works. Also I had my main client work with UTC@MediaCityUK. And then myself personally. The work out looks like this…

As you can see my start up project and training company didn’t get much love or attention in January. Funnily enough the side project FFFlip closed the next month.

We can do the same analysis on how many short, medium or long term focused actions you are taking. And so whether your focus has on “sharpening the saw” enough i.e. on mid and longer term goals.

For myself, the longer term goals are things like blogging, or enhancing my marketing skills, or deepening networking relationships. Whereas short term goals might be something which is achieved in a month like setting up the media buying campaigns or doing a report.

For January — my to do list achievements looked like this. Quite near to the 60 / 30 / 10 split that I like to uphold. And apols on the maths maybe not being perfect…

To Rewards:

So now you have your list. It’s time to reward yourself.

This is my favourite part of the system (actually it’s not — as I am odd) but there you have it. Rewards are put in as human beings like rewards. Some would argue we work for rewards i.e. a wage etc.

Rewards tend to be motivational but to be honest I put them in to make sure I don’t go “work crazy” and forget I am human too. My old life coach insisted I used rewards and it has worked pretty well.

So for each 5 or 10 things you do — give yourself a reward. I do 20 things. Which looks like this:

As you can see with my rewards I see whether they are short term i.e. instant gratification like playing on a computer game. Or more longer term i.e. cultivating relationships with friends. Or family commitments. Everything is written down and thought about… Everything is examined.

As you can see the perfect “to do list” has several features.

  1. Short. Medium. Long Term thinking.
  2. Elements that re work on your motivation centres i.e. Knowing your why.
  3. A rewards system which increases with the amount of work done.

So I hope you enjoy using it. Adapt it. Take out your favorite bits.

Do comment below. I do love your comments.

— — — — — — — — -

Extra note…

It took a LOT of time to write this post. For some reason I had a lot of resistance internally against writing it. Maybe it was my little secret. I think deep down I didn’t want everyone to use it for free. But heck — it’s down now so… Share with the world.

If you liked this post then do remember to click the thumbs up button below. And remember sharing is caring :)

And, of course, feel free to also connect via Twitter.

About Me:

Dan Sodergren is a professional speaker and digital marketing trainer based in Manchester with Great Marketing Works. He specialises in mobile and social marketing with ideas ranging from augmented reality, to RTB and back again.

He trains companies and individuals in best practice on social and mobile marketing platforms, gets to talk about it all on radio and is even occasionally seen on the BBC.

— — — — — — — — — — — -

Extra Note 2:

Now for the clincher…

I have spent the past five years perfecting this to do list. And now I am ripping it up. For a month at least. To focus on happiness. On #InternationalHappinessDay and the start of spring — a week from my 41st Birthday. But why?

In January I did more actions than ever. More than 200.

And yet… Have I been happier. Sadly not. I haven’t had time to be ;)

So on the day of the beginning of spring, a week after my birthday, at a time of the vernal equinox, a 6 monthly moment of balance, I am going to do the unspeakable to a coach. I am ripping up my to do list. As productivity might not be what I seek after all.

Oh and after five years — I may have got my percentages right but the items to focus on all wrong. Check out this article here about 60 / 30 /10 … It’s probably why I have never had a career… That and that I started my own businesses from the age of 17… It makes for very interesting reading.
